title: EIP-8141: Frame Transaction
description: Adds a new transaction type whose validity and gas payment can be defined abstractly. Instead of relying on a single ECDSA signature, accounts may freely define and interpret their signature scheme using any cryptographic system, enabling post-quantum security and native account abstraction.
author: Vitalik Buterin (@vbuterin), lightclient (@lightclient), Felix Lange (@fjl), Yoav Weiss (@yoavw), Alex Forshtat (@forshtat), Dror Tirosh (@drortirosh), Shahaf Nacson (@shahafn)
laymanDescription: Allows smart accounts to verify transactions using any cryptographic method instead of only ECDSA signatures, enabling post-quantum security and flexible fee payment including gas sponsorship.

improveUX.description: Enables native account abstraction with flexible validation and gas sponsorship, allowing smart wallets with better security, recovery options, and gasless transactions.

endUsers.description: Enables smart accounts with custom signing schemes, post-quantum security, and sponsored transactions.

appDevs.description: Can integrate gas sponsorship and leverage new smart account capabilities for better UX.

walletDevs.description: Must implement new transaction type and support arbitrary validation logic in smart accounts.

toolingInfra.description: Need to support new transaction format, receipt structure, and per-frame status tracking.

layer2s.description: Can adopt the same transaction type for consistent cross-layer account abstraction.

stakersNodes.description: Must enforce mempool validation rules similar to ERC-7562 to prevent DoS attacks.

clClients.description: No direct impact on consensus layer.

elClients.description: Major work: new tx type, APPROVE and TXPARAM opcodes, multi-frame execution, and per-frame receipts.

benefits: Provides native off-ramp to post-quantum secure cryptography
Enables flexible gas sponsorship and ERC-20 fee payment
Supports native batched transactions with per-frame receipts
Unifies account abstraction at the protocol level
tradeoffs: Introduces new DoS vectors requiring mempool validation rules
Changes ORIGIN opcode behavior for frame transactions
